title: Ken Fisher’s Firm Sees Growing Client Exodus
text:
Text size

The cost of Ken Fisher’s sexually explicit remarks earlier this month continues to rise.

The state pension fund of Texas is withdrawing $350 million from Fisher Investments, Bloomberg reports. “With respect to our fiduciary duty, we are defunding Fisher Investments,” the pension said in a statement Friday.

Earlier, CNBC reported that investment bank Goldman Sachs is pulling $234 million. Goldman and Fisher Investments declined to comment to the news outlet.

And the Goldman news came not long after Bloomberg reported that the Los Angeles fire and police pension was yanking $511 million from the firm.

The three investors join Fidelity Investments and five pension funds in divesting from the large RIA following its founder and chairman’s remarks at a closed-door industry summit on Oct. 8. Accounting for Texas, outflows now total more than $3.1 billion, according to Bloomberg.

The decision by Los Angeles on Thursday followed what Bloomberg described as a “contentious” pension board meeting with Fisher representatives.

“Fisher’s words reach millions and only do damage,” Los Angeles pension commissioner Brian Pendleton said at the meeting. “Other pension funds are going to come to the same conclusion and we shouldn’t be the last ones to turn the lights off.”

Fisher Investments’ CEO, Damian Ornani, apologized for Ken Fisher. (When the scandal first erupted, Fisher initially expressed surprise his comments had offended listeners; later he issued a full apology.)

“I really apologize sincerely,” Mr. Ornani said at the meeting, according to Bloomberg. “He does too. He understands what he did. This will not happen again. This is not who Fisher Investments is. This is not who Ken Fisher is.”

But Adam Nathanson, the president of the pension board asked why Ken Fisher didn’t show up for the meeting and whether he has offered to resign. A representative from the firm said its founder was too important to Fisher Investments to resign.

One one crisis PR manager tells Financial Advisor IQ that Fisher’s resignation is exactly what’s needed for his firm to staunch the outflow of clients.

“It’s time for him not just to resign, but rather to announce his retirement and, as an author, go to work on his next book with a mea culpa-like theme,” Marco Greenberg, president of Thunder11, tells the publication.

--Ross Snel
description: Texas, Goldman Sachs and Los Angeles reportedly join the exodus of institutional clients from Fisher Investments.
